NSA discussions um and it's it's part of the uh reasoning behind why it's okay to gather
this uh metadata basically the third party Doctrine says that
um that if you give up your information such as telephone uh metadata that
you've given it to another company you don't have an expectation of privacy so the government doesn't need a warrant to
get it um and you know this has been the case since
1979 um and there was there were some earlier cases that were related to that as well um but it's now now that we have

wasn't a majority opinion but within the Supreme Court um Justice
Sodor actually raised this issue and um and pointed out that this concept that
has been standard legal Doctrine for decades is actually no longer suited to
um our our digital age so I think um this is another thing to to think about
my experience with this concept that's been around for more than 30 years at this point is that it's actually still news to most people that the government
can get your information without a warrant if you've given it up to a to a third party
um and you know it's worth considering whether the laws that
um are being used to uh access uh systems or gather people's information

okay um so I'm uh Matt blae I'm a professor at the University of
Pennsylvania and I'm a computer scientist who studies among other things uh surveillance and surveillance
technology um so I'm just going to talk about a a couple of things the purpose
of this panel was to talk about what how should you react if you are given a
secret surveillance order uh from the government to turn over information that you know that you've got in the course
of your business or about your users or or what have you something like the scary Kafkaesque experience that rooster
was describing where you get a national security letter and you are um told not only to
turn over this information that you might not have collected in a form that
um the government is precisely asking for but you can't actually get anyone's advice um you can't tell any anyone
about it you can't um resist it without some risk of being found in violation of
a court order um the natural thing to do I mean you know certainly personally
what I would do as a very much died in the wool coward uh is is comply um and
I'm grateful that we have brave people like Brewster who will push back um to
to um uh to say hey wait a minute maybe this is unreasonable but I think the
majority of us will will say well listen it's it's in my interest to just to just comply with this and have it go away as
soon as possible what I'd like to talk about very briefly is what we may lose if we do that from a technical point of
view um we've talked a lot about what we what we lose from a civil liberties point of view but there's there's
another another risk of secret surveillance infra uh infrastructure and
secret surveillance um yeah Secret surveillance
interfaces that are put in very quietly in order to uh respond to an order that
you immediately get that you weren't prepared for and what are you going to naturally do as a technologist if you if
you get such a thing well you're going to put together some software and some hardware and some interconnections as
absolutely quickly as possible to comply with it and as we all know writing
software uh is a very easy process and you always get it right the first time
and there's never anything wrong with what you initially do and it never has any implications that you didn't
anticipate when you first um when when you first implemented it um and in
particular software is particularly better if you can't ask anyone to test it for you um and this is effectively
what we what we get asked to do when we have a a secret surveillance order now we don't know very much about how
national security letters get complied with what kinds of mechanisms are used
to collect and deliver to the government um the information requested in a
national security letter because it's secret um what we we can assume that
these are put together relatively hurriedly and we can assume that they are in general customized for each
person who gets it each person who gets it each company that gets it has to figure out how to comply pretty much
entirely on their own um but we don't know much about what those mechanisms are we can't scrutinize them we can't
debug them we can't ask if they have other implications or are creating other weaknesses because they're they're
secret um one of the problems is that we've found that when the government in the law enforcement context law
enforcement wir Taps um are um uh
certainly uh more prominent than National Security wir Taps but we know
that one thing one property of government wir Taps is that the people who are asking to have them wiretapped
have a priority what they are rewarded for what they are judged by is solving
crime right the purpose of a wiretap is to solve an existing crime and what nobody we have found in um wiretaps is
asking is whether the implementation of this Crim solving technology creates the
opportunity for new crime that wasn't there by weakening our our
infrastructure and in fact invariably what we've discovered is that creating
interfaces to facilitate wiretapping makes systems weaker it's a security
vulnerability that's built in from the beginning we've seen this in a number of of of ways uh the most prominent the
most OB obious um is What's called the Kalia interfaces in um telephone systems
uh Kalia is a standard wiretapped system that all telephone switches are required
to implement in the United States and um that allows the government to get access
to to call content and metadata when they have a legal authority to do so um
one of the things that we've discovered is that uh every Kalia system that was evaluated by the National Security
Agency when the government was buying phone switches for its own use were
found to have security holes in them um and so in order to you know enable
wiretapping to solve one set of crimes were opening up these phone switches for new sets of crimes similarly in Greece
in 2004 there was something called the Athens Affair in which um uh in which
over a 100 government officials were found to be wiretapped and we never found out who who did it we just found
that the wiretap interfaces were turned on a similar thing happened in Italy in 2006 again these wiretap interfaces just
got turned on we don't know who did it we don't know um what the motive was um and um uh what we do know is that in
order to um you know comply with this we had this you know massive wiretapping
that would not have happened if it weren't for this Crim solving technology
so one of the questions we have to ask is how do we balance crime solving with
creating risks of new crimes from a technological point of view um uh
another example of this is what happens when you say well listen I don't have
any ability to comply with this wiretap order you're asking me for something that I can't technically do well in 20
and the FBI um proposed a solution to this problem for for example internet
providers who are unable to uh provide an internet connection which was oh don't worry about it let us just come
into your um Data Center and we'll install this box on your network that
will collect the data that we need and oh don't worry this box has been very
carefully vetted um and it won't affect your network or collect anything more
than it was otherwise supposed to collect so this is with wiretapping that's relatively open in the criminal
world for criminal wir Taps there's much less secrecy than there is in the
National Security cases and here we've seen that the balance even with this
scrutiny creates crime while it's attempting to solve it on the National
Security side we essentially have the same um reward system the national secur
authorities are there to prevent um and solve terrorist uh activities but
they're not uh there to protect the infrastructure and it's all under the cloak of of of secrecy so from a
technological point of view whatever you think of the civil liberty side um this
may not be um actually buying us what we're trying to get so let me turn it
over to [Applause]

good afternoon uh my name is Alan Davidson I am a visiting scholar at MIT but my uh claim to fame I think for
being on this panel right now is that uh uh for probably about 7even years prior
to that starting in 2005 I was the director of public policy for Google uh in North and South America I started
Google's office in Washington and dealt with some of these issues as they came up uh for the company uh and before that
actually was a director at the center for democracy and Technology where I actually lobbied against some of these
provisions of the Patriot Act um and I I'm here to really talk about uh uh not
the technical piece but the the legal and business and public policy reasons
for you to be asking questions uh for all of us to be asking questions about the uh law enforcement and National
Security requests that we receive uh so first from a legal perspective I should say uh when you get a request uh the fir
your first stop should be to talk to your lawyer uh good job Brewster um I do think they train us to say this in law
school by the way but um uh uh you know the odds are that you will have to
comply with the orders that you receive but there is as we've already discussed some great ambiguity in the law and um
what I don't think is widely understood uh but is well understood I think among many of the lawyers who deal with these
things is that there is often a great deal of room for negotiation about the
methods or terms of compliance for the orders uh that are given and not always but in a lot of cases um I think it's
just worth recognizing right law enforcement National Security agents they have a job to do they're seeking the most information they can get uh to
prosecute somebody who they think is bad uh go or stop something that they think is uh is dangerous but there's a lot of
ambiguity in the way that these statutes are drafted we talked briefly just about what does the word relevant what is what
is relevant to an investigation mean and so what you often find what we often seen is that it's common to get very
broad orders uh that ultimately are not that responsive to the case at hand and
maybe not even helpful to the FBI or whoever else you're getting the order from uh it's it is very difficult to
discuss specifics but I can talk about one one good story from the early days at my early days at Google um uh uh that
that was public um and it was in 2006 and like all good internet stories uh it
involves uh pornography um so the at the time this the justice department was trying to um uh defend a
statute called Copa that CH child children's online protection act is ultimately found unconstitutional it's a
it said that you couldn't uh commercially display certain harmful to miners material online way ways that kids could see them but in sort of last
ditch effort to try to defend this law the justice department thought it would be a great idea to subpoena the search
records from all of the major search providers two months worth of search records for everybody in the United States from Microsoft AOL Yahoo Google
and others and um most of those other companies complied with the subpoena but
when we got the subpoena at Google we were quite surprised because two months worth of search records is quite a
number of Records it was literally billions and billions of records and we could not well first of all I couldn't
understand why they would actually need it and second of all seemed quite dangerous to be giving it out and and setting a terrible precedent a lot of
private information in there uh so we because this happened to be a civil case we were able to moved to quash The
subpoena uh there was a lot of discussion we were actually able to get in front of a judge and ultimately uh
the judge found in fact that this was not relevant this did not meet the standards for the that were needed for
this particular kind of subpoena and uh ultimately reduced this request for
billions of Records down to uh ultimately Google had to produce 5,000
random search queries and they were um there was a process that the judge came through so that you didn't actually have to give out IP addresses or even what
was in the queries they were just categorize but the the point of this is by asking and pushing back we were able
to narrow this from billions of Records to 5,000 records and um that may be the
high water mark your mileage may vary our mileage varied widely but the point is that a lot of times simply by asking
questions you can uh and sometimes when you can Brewster is a great example you can actually push back on these things
the second thing a quick business perspective we all know trust is essential people are not going to use
our product if they don't trust them uh and they aren't going to trust them if we can't protect their privacy and
security the data shows that you that that people actually do care quite a bit about uh their privacy they care quite
about a bit about it in the context of this uh debate that we're having now and I would just note that secret
surveillance scales particularly poorly internationally right if you are a
European government right now looking for a cloud computing provider or a storage provider are you going to use
Amazon services are you going to adopt Google Docs I think probably a lot of people are thinking they'd be crazy to
do that right now um and they shouldn't feel that way I think there are good reasons they shouldn't feel that way but
I think there's a real risk that we are going to see a real impact on businesses
because of these Revelations and because of the lack of transparency around them and the risk there especially is that
we're going to see a balkanization where people insist on keeping their data in places that they can see it in inside
their country they don't to stop wanting that uh the kind of free flow of information and traffic that has made in
some ways uh a lot of our services and a lot of things on the internet successful and I would just say also
beyond the business impact I think that has a very big impact on the NSA and on the FBI and all of our law enforcement
establishments ability to do this kind of surveillance right I think we live in a golden age of wiretapping right now uh
especially for the US Services it's true I mean I think that uh we're very lucky that in the United that that many of the
most successful uh Brands online happen to be us companies they're very popular
uh abroad and because of that um we've given uh our our government an ability
to get access to information that other governments would really like and uh over time if we're not transparent about
these tools if we're not able to give people good answers about how they're being used we really risk driving the
data away the very data that our law enforcement and National Security establishment needs in some cases um so
uh I think there are important business and national security reasons we should be asking hard questions the last thing I will say is about quickly about the
public policy debate we could talk about this more in the Q&A too um I think it's
largely understood that the law enforcement establishment and National Security establishment need access to
information to protect us right um the question is not whether they should be able to get any information I think the
question is uh what over what are the rules going to be what oversight is in
place and I think Americans have a highly stylized view of how all of this
works right we've seen it on TV if you want to seize my laptop from my home you have to go to a judge you have to get a
warrant you know the judge has to say that there's probable cause you have to knock on my door show me the order I can
